title: Ideal font stacks for web
content:
I've seen a lot of rubbish out there about font stacks for web use, so I wanted to see if we could come up with some better ones. It's a matter up for much debate, but I'd like to see what we can come up with.

Here is my contribution. Feel free to rip it to shreds, and add/delete. Apologies in advance to Linux users.

"Humanist Sans":  
`font-family: "Gill Sans", "Gill Sans MT", "Gill Sans Std", GoudySans, "ITC Goudy Sans Std", "Myriad Pro", "Myriad Web", "Myriad Std", "Bitstream Vera Sans", Verdana, sans-serif;`

"Oldstyle":  
`font-family: "Adobe Jenson Pro", "Hoefler Text", "Centaur", "Centaur MT", "Garamond Premier Pro", "Stempel Garamond", "Adobe Garamond Pro", "Adobe Garamond", Garamond, Georgia, serif;`

"Geometric Sans": \<\<- My worst one. Needs help.  
`font-family: "Futura", "Century Gothic, "Tw Cen MT", "Gill Sans", "Gill Sans MT", "Gill Sans Std", "URW Gothic L", sans-serif;`
author: Dan Gayle

comments.content:
The only fonts that guarantee cross browser compatibility are Georgia for serif, Verdana for sans. Times New Roman, and Helvetica could be good secondaries.

Great [article](http://web.archive.org/web/20120211003116/http:/www.3point7designs.com/blog/2008/05/08/8-fonts-you-probably-dont-use-in-css-but-should/) discussing increasingly compatible system fonts.

A bit dated now but still useful: [http://media.24ways.org/2007/17/fontmatrix.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20120211003116/http:/media.24ways.org/2007/17/fontmatrix.html "http://media.24ways.org/2007/17/fontmatrix.html")
Which brings up the topic of @fontface. Anyone know the status of font embedding? Will IE support OTF in the future? Or will Microsoft's EOT be the standard for web fonts?
